text:
Wade schools Winslow in art of the undersized post game Dwyane Wade discusses mentoring Justise Winslow 
Dwyane Wade has been mentoring Justise Winslow during training camp, especially about the post game. 
Dwyane Wade has been mentoring Justise Winslow during training camp, especially about the post game. Ira Winderman Contact Reporter South Florida Sun Sentinel School is in session when Dwyane Wade works with Justise Winslow 
Justise Winslow left Duke after a single championship season. Dwyane Wade spent Friday making sure that the rookie's basketball education didn't end there. 
So after Miami Heat practice was over at AmericanAirlines Arena, Wade took time to school the prized first-round pick on the essentials of undersized post play, drilling with Winslow in front of assistant coach David Fizdale. 
"It's just passing down knowledge to someone who I think could be good at things I think I have strengths at," Wade said after the tutorial. "It's going to take a while. But if he figures it out at 21, he's ahead of the curve. I figured it out at like 27. So I'm just trying to help him get ahead." 
At 19, Winslow already has had plenty of schooling from NBA veterans. His father, Rickie Winslow, played in the NBA and while growing up in Houston the younger Winslow often would gravitate to the gym of former NBA guard John Lucas, who has made a career of mentoring NBA players. 
"Growing up in Houston, working out with Coach Lucas, now playing with his son, he always had pros in the gym, all type of guys," Winslow said, with John Lucas III among those also in Heat training camp. "Dad played professionally, so I've been around a lot of pros in my life."
